text:
Hey everyone, I'm curious; i've been getting enquiries lately from a few companies who have an inhouse content writer but want me to help them get more out of their content writers to achieve more leads AND craft a proper content strategy for them. Is this a thing? If you're a content writer, do you get directions from someone else and simply write, OR do you do both? I'm curious what the norm is.
This is because I'm thinking if it's worth offering a service where I help assess the effectiveness of their content and align content production with their goals, for a monthly fee. Thoughts? Maybe there are already great tools out there.

elements.text:

This is because I'm thinking if it's worth offering a service where I help assess the effectiveness of their content and align content production with their goals, for a monthly fee. Thoughts? Maybe there are already great tools out there.

text: Hi Rachel! Most of the time when I talk to freelance writing clients they already have their own strategy and are just looking for someone to implement. I have worked with those who are looking for assistance in content strategy as well but those are rarer.

elements.text: Hi Rachel! Most of the time when I talk to freelance writing clients they already have their own strategy and are just looking for someone to implement. I have worked with those who are looking for assistance in content strategy as well but those are rarer.

text: I think Animalz launched this exact offering earlier this year(?), so I assume there’s a demand there. Someone from their team can probably give you more insight!

elements.text: I think Animalz launched this exact offering earlier this year(?), so I assume there’s a demand there. Someone from their team can probably give you more insight!

text: :hugging_face: Thanks y'all! Really helpful.

elements.text: Thanks y'all! Really helpful.

text: I’m strictly a content writer and I work with 2 content strategists. they craft the strategy and send me briefs, but I also have the freedom to add to the brief (especially if I’ve been writing one topic cluster for a while — I might have more insight into a particular topic). we also have a fairly large marketing team so that might be why we’re able to have team members who just write and some who build the strategy! but I think it really does depend on the size and structure of the marketing team. before I joined, our content strategists were also writing the majority of the content. so there is most likely demand for marketers who can write, do SEO, and develop a strategy!

text: Hi everyone! I was wondering if any of you have taken a solid course on editing that you'd recommend? I'm trying to transition out of writing full-time and working more on content strategy,  conversion, and optimization. My boss suggested I work on becoming a stronger editor in order to help my team better create content. Let me know if you know of any resources!

text:
Hey Rachel! This is definitely a thing, though what it looks like can vary between startup and established companies. (As Alessia pointed out...it depends on the team!)

One strategist I know said startups often need "done-with-you" strategy whereas more established companies pursue "done-for-you."

Some consultants even separate the services you listed. Assessing the effectiveness would be an audit or included in discovery. Crafting strategy would be a separate piece.

I'm a content writer and I work with startups on execution. I report to a content strategist for one of my clients, and I love it.

Here are some people who do what you're describing:
• <https://kierantie.com/work-with-me>
• <https://www.adriennenakohl.com/>
• <https://www.hiredaisy.com/content-marketing-services/>

text:
<@U013P4Q9YTU> Of course! I'm super ashamed to admit I'm not a member, but it's mostly out of laziness and the fact that you get access to a lot their resources without being a member. For instance, the webinar series I sent you to is entirely free for members and non-members.

But I will become a member because I believe in supporting them, and normally, one webinar is usually around $30, so if you attend even a couple of sessions, that annual membership has pretty much paid for itself. And you get a generous discount for their annual event as a member.

text:
Thanks for the shoutout <@UL4TUV38B>!

<@U0153M0K2N7> I've done both writing and strategy for clients in the last 12mo, along with subcontract writing for Animalz. I've definitely also seen a need for what you're describing - a "done with you" service for bootstrapped founders and indie entrepreneurs that's cheaper than DFY content, but more thorough than just writing.

The struggle is scaling it down to a pricepoint that's affordable - since that audience is always on a tight budget, I've found that getting them to buy into strategy is more difficult. Most founders on limited budgets also can't afford to invest in "unknowns" - projects with fuzzy timelines, unclear deliverables, etc.

I'm getting ready to soft-launch a new service targeting exactly this problem - <https://kierantie.com/product/one-day-blog-strategy>. Reduced-scope blog strategy with the aim of helping them establish a content workflow, whether they do the writing or hire someone else to write for them. The one-day thing is a risk, but alleviates many concerns I've noted around what deliverables they get, how long the process takes, etc. Basically, a done-with-you content cookbook, all in one day.

Happy to bounce ideas, or answer any questions you have - DMs are always open!

text: Who here has experience with "testing" content? i.e. how do you determine if the content you've created is suitable for your intended audience, and is easy to understand and comprehend? What sorts of tests do you run? And what sorts of tools/softwares do you use? I'm writing an article on the subject and would love to get some perspectives from fellow marketers!

elements.text: Who here has experience with "testing" content? i.e. how do you determine if the content you've created is suitable for your intended audience, and is easy to understand and comprehend? What sorts of tests do you run? And what sorts of tools/softwares do you use? I'm writing an article on the subject and would love to get some perspectives from fellow marketers!

text: the only way i’ve ever been able to really do this is by getting on sales calls. if people talk about your content, cite specific ideas, ask follow-up questions, etc. then it’s working

elements.text: the only way i’ve ever been able to really do this is by getting on sales calls. if people talk about your content, cite specific ideas, ask follow-up questions, etc. then it’s working

text:
A few ideas <@UUE7J6UDN>

1. A/B testing content headlines to see which performs better; Depending on the tool, you could technically customize more within it (intro paragraphs, images, etc.) to see what performs--but I’ve never gone beyond headlines.
2. Testing concepts through paid ads and seeing clickthrough rates could also indicate “hey, this is a topic/offer my core audience is interested in/understands.” As an example, we’ve found some topics/terms in ads perform better than others--so we focus on using that for our content strategy since it’s resonating.
3. If possible, use a customer community to test content and collect feedback. (Hop on calls, do a poll/form after they read it, etc.) Partner communities/contacts could also be good for this. 
4. Re: is it readable/understandable--set up a poll at the end and just ask :slightly_smiling_face: Could use free forms, a paid polling tool like Qualtrics, a social polling mechanism (LI and Twitter have them).

Hope some of this is helpful brainstorming. Good luck with the article.

elements.text: A few ideas

A/B testing content headlines to see which performs better; Depending on the tool, you could technically customize more within it (intro paragraphs, images, etc.) to see what performs--but I’ve never gone beyond headlines.

Testing concepts through paid ads and seeing clickthrough rates could also indicate “hey, this is a topic/offer my core audience is interested in/understands.” As an example, we’ve found some topics/terms in ads perform better than others--so we focus on using that for our content strategy since it’s resonating.
If possible, use a customer community to test content and collect feedback. (Hop on calls, do a poll/form after they read it, etc.) Partner communities/contacts could also be good for this.
4. Re: is it readable/understandable--set up a poll at the end and just ask

Could use free forms, a paid polling tool like Qualtrics, a social polling mechanism (LI and Twitter have them).

Hope some of this is helpful brainstorming. Good luck with the article.

text: I've used the highlighter test with clients and potential clients and have loved the process. Here's an article that Sara Walsh (formerly at Capital One, now at Google) that explains it well. I've done it remotely using Google Docs. Super easy. <https://medium.com/capitalonedesign/when-should-we-turn-to-content-testing-429f8bddf622>

attachments.title: When Should We Turn to Content Testing?
attachments.text: A primer on a great UX research method to help you design the conversation and evaluate the effectiveness of your words
attachments.fallback: Medium: When Should We Turn to Content Testing?

text: Hi, everyone. Most of my projects are in the content strategy/content design space and are based on a flat fee. That said, I've been approached about a few hourly copywriting gigs (including one from a household name) and they're asking for an hourly rate. Can you think of any great resources I could look at for context so I don't over- or under-price myself in the current market?

elements.text: Hi, everyone. Most of my projects are in the content strategy/content design space and are based on a flat fee. That said, I've been approached about a few hourly copywriting gigs (including one from a household name) and they're asking for an hourly rate. Can you think of any great resources I could look at for context so I don't over- or under-price myself in the current market?

text: Try this: <https://allfreelancewriting.com/freelance-hourly-rate-calculator/>

text: Thanks, <@U012GHRAHDK> and <@U016BDEQ40J>. I've seen both of these, and they're interesting, but they're not quite what I'm looking for. I really want a better sense of what other people are charging, not what I'm worth. the latter drives much of my work, but in this particular case I don't want to price myself out of the phone interview before I pitch my value.

text: <@UJ7R3QGSV> that is an awesome idea. We struggle the same thing in terms of budget, content creation and strategy. <@U0153M0K2N7> I totally agree - that’s where we come in too ;) however we prefer to work with small marketing teams (like 1-4). We do work with owners but you’re always fighting for their time. And convincing them of untested/new/updated strategy can be hard because the language barrier. The marketing team gets it but there is a risk that they may happen to find an amazing writer/photographer/SEO/graphic designer in one person :face_with_rolling_eyes:

text: In that case, you can maybe compare full-time salaries and work out your rates? LinkedIn Salary & Glassdoor are trustworthy.

elements.text: In that case, you can maybe compare full-time salaries and work out your rates? LinkedIn Salary & Glassdoor are trustworthy.

text:
I'm based near San Francisco and for my large enterprise clients, I generally require at least $60/hour W2.  Corp to corp engagements for enterprise clients are at least $70/hour.

For smaller companies, my hourly rate starts at $50/hour. Exact rates vary by complexity and amount of research required.

Those rates are based on what I've seen as the going rates with my colleagues and various roles with funded startups and larger organizations.

elements.text:

Those rates are based on what I've seen as the going rates with my colleagues and various roles with funded startups and larger organizations.

text: Hi everyone. A prospective client wants help optimizing and rewriting some huge guides (free 30 day courses) she has on her site. I've never done a project like this so I'm wondering how to charge for it. Considering I won't be writing the post from scratch, do I still quote my regular per word rate and charge for the entire length of the guide? Or do I give a flat fee for each guide? Thanks:slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi everyone. A prospective client wants help optimizing and rewriting some huge guides (free 30 day courses) she has on her site. I've never done a project like this so I'm wondering how to charge for it. Considering I won't be writing the post from scratch, do I still quote my regular per word rate and charge for the entire length of the guide? Or do I give a flat fee for each guide? Thanks
